tasks: Create a simple wireframe of a login form using the 8-point grid system, focusing on proper alignment and spacing.
Write down 5 common UX principles (heuristics) that you've learned so far, such as 'visibility of system status' or 'user control and freedom'.
Sketch out a basic user flow for a hypothetical app, highlighting the most critical steps for a new user to complete their first task.
Redesign your own login form using the 8-point grid system, incorporating at least one of the UX principles from Week 1.
Create a list of 10 common error messages that users encounter when interacting with digital products, and categorize them into 'critical' or 'non-critical'.
Develop a simple heuristic evaluation checklist for your own designs, focusing on usability and accessibility.
Conduct an A/B test using the Law of Proximity to compare two versions of a button's placement in a navigation bar. Document your findings.
Write a short essay (approx. 250 words) explaining how Tesler’s Law applies to your current design work, and provide examples from your own projects.
Create an annotated wireframe of a hypothetical app, highlighting specific design decisions that demonstrate the Aesthetic-Usability Effect.
Design a comprehensive usability test plan for a new feature in a product you're familiar with, incorporating at least three user research methods.
Develop an advanced heuristic evaluation checklist for your own designs, focusing on usability and accessibility. Document your process and results.
Create a case study (approx. 500 words) of a successful design project that demonstrates your understanding of UX principles and strategies.

resources.readup: As an Explorer UX designer, you have the unique opportunity to uncover new insights and create innovative solutions that transform user experiences. To excel in this role, focus on bridging gaps in your skills by developing a deeper understanding of UX fundamentals, refining your visual design skills, and honing your research and collaboration abilities.

resources.title: 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design
resources.description: 7 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design ================================================= Jakob Nielsen ![](https://media.nngroup.com/medi...

topics.name: Understanding Tesler's Law for Improved Navigation
topics.summary: Tesler's Law states that the more complex a system, the less intuitive it becomes. By applying this law, you can design more efficient navigation and reduce cognitive load.
practice_points: Create 3 wireframes of a navigation menu with varying levels of complexity (e.g., simple, moderate, complex) to demonstrate how Tesler's Law impacts user experience.

topics.name: Applying the Zeigarnik Effect to Enhance User Engagement
topics.summary: The Zeigarnik Effect suggests that unfinished tasks leave a lasting impression on users. By incorporating this principle into your design, you can increase user engagement and retention.
practice_points: Design 2 interactive prototypes with an 'unfinished task' element (e.g., a partially completed form or a paused game) to observe how the Zeigarnik Effect affects user behavior.

topics.name: Conducting User Research using the Jobs-to-be-Done Framework
topics.summary: The Jobs-to-be-Done framework helps you understand users' motivations and goals. By conducting user research with this framework, you can design solutions that meet users' needs more effectively.
practice_points: Conduct 2 user interviews using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework and document findings to identify patterns and insights.

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating a need to improve foundational skills in user experience design.
insights.detailed: The low score suggests that the designer may struggle with creating user-centered designs, understanding user behavior, and designing intuitive interfaces. This could lead to poor user engagement and satisfaction with the product.
actionable: Take online courses or attend workshops to improve UX fundamentals knowledge
Study successful design systems and case studies to understand best practices
Join online communities or forums to connect with experienced designers and learn from their experiences

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating a need to improve visual design skills.
insights.detailed: The moderate score suggests that the designer has some knowledge of UI craft and visual design principles, but may struggle with creating visually appealing and consistent designs. This could lead to a lack of brand recognition and user trust in the product.
actionable: Practice designing for different platforms and devices to improve adaptability
Study color theory, typography, and composition to enhance visual design skills
Create a personal project or contribute to open-source designs to build portfolio

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating a need to improve research and validation skills.
insights.detailed: The moderate score suggests that the designer has some knowledge of user research methods, but may struggle with conducting effective user testing and validating design decisions. This could lead to poor understanding of user needs and pain points.
actionable: Take online courses or attend workshops on user research methods
Conduct user interviews and usability testing to gain hands-on experience
Join online communities or forums to learn from other researchers and validate findings

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating a need to improve product thinking and strategy skills.
insights.detailed: The moderate score suggests that the designer has some knowledge of product development principles, but may struggle with creating business-driven design decisions. This could lead to poor alignment between design and business goals.
actionable: Study successful product strategies and case studies to understand business drivers
Take online courses or attend workshops on product thinking and strategy
Join online communities or forums to connect with product managers and learn from their experiences

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating a need to improve collaboration and communication skills.
insights.detailed: The moderate score suggests that the designer has some knowledge of effective collaboration techniques, but may struggle with communicating design decisions and working with cross-functional teams. This could lead to misunderstandings and delays in project timelines.
actionable: Practice collaborating on group projects or contributing to open-source initiatives
Take online courses or attend workshops on effective communication skills
Join online communities or forums to learn from other designers and improve collaboration strategies
